Ancient History.subject: Ancient History
Ancient History.question: The Harappan site at Kot Diji is close to which one of the following major sites of that civilization?
Ancient History.explanation: The ancient site at Kot Diji was the forerunner of the Indus Civilization. The remains consist of two parts; the citadel area on high ground (about 12 m), and outer area. The Pakistan Department of Archaeology excavated at Kot Diji in 1955 and 1957.Located about 24 kilometers south of Khairpur in the province of Sindh, Pakistan, it is on the east bank of the Indus opposite Mohenjo-daro.

Ancient History.subject: Ancient History
Ancient History.question: According to the Tamil Sangam texts, who among the following were the large landowners?
Ancient History.explanation: The large landowners were known as the Vellalar according to the Tamil Sangam. The cultivators were known as the uzhavar, and it was the kadaisiyar who were the labourers and adimai who were the slaves.

Ancient History.subject: Ancient History
Ancient History.question: According to the Manusmriti, women can acquire wealth through which of the following means?
Ancient History.explanation: Manusmriti provides a woman with property rights to six types of property in verses 9.192-9.200. These include those she received at her marriage, or as gift when she eloped or when she was taken away, or as token of love before marriage, or as gifts from her biological family, or as received from her husband subsequent to marriage, and also from inheritance from deceased relatives.

Ancient History.subject: Ancient History
Ancient History.question: The dialogue on Varna between king Avantiputta and Kachchana, a disciple of Buddha, appears in which one of the following Buddhist texts?
Ancient History.explanation: The story, based on a Buddhist text in Pali known as the Majjhima Nikaya, is part of a dialogue between a king named Avantiputta and a disciple of the Buddha named Kachchana. While it may not be literally true, it reveals Buddhist attitudes towards varna.

Ancient History.subject: Ancient History
Ancient History.question: In the first century AD, which among the following was not a major item of Indian exports to Rome?
Ancient History.explanation: Tortoiseshell was not a major item of Indian exports to Rome.

Modern History.subject: Modern History
Modern History.question:
Which of the following statements relating to the Government of In dia Act, 1858 is/are correct?
1. The British Crown assumed sovereignty over India from the East India Company.
2. The British Parliament enacted the first statute for the governance of India under the direct rule of the British.
3. This Act was dominated by the principle of absolute imperial control without any popular participation in the administration of the country.
Select the correct answer using the code given below.
Modern History.explanation: Government of India Act 1858 provided that India was to be governed directly and in the name of the crown. The office of secretary of state was vested with complete authority and control over Indian administration, thus he was now the political head of the India.

Modern History.subject: Modern History
Modern History.question:
Which of the following statements relating to the Indian Councils Act, 1861 is / are correcr~
1. The Act introduced a grain of popular element by including non-official members in the Governor-General’s Executive Council.
2. The members were nominated and their functions were confined exclusively to consideration of legislative proposals placed before it by the Governor-General.
3. The Governor-General did not have effective legislative power.
Select the correct answer using the code given below.
Modern History.explanation: The executive council of Governor General was added a fifth finance member. For legislative purpose, a provision was made for an addition of 6 to 12 members to the central executive. At least half of the additional members were to be non-officials. Governor –General had the power of making rules and regulations for the conduct of business of executive council.

Modern History.subject: Modern History
Modern History.question:
Which of the following statements relating to the historic Objectives Resolution, which was adopted by the Constituent Assembly, is/are correct?
1. The Objectives Resolution inspired the shaping of the Constitution through all its subsequent stages.
2. It was not just a resolution, but a declaration, a firm resolve and a pledge.
3. It provided the underlying philosophy of our Constitution.
Select the correct answer using the code given below.
Modern History.explanation: Objectives Resolution (the resolution that defined the aims of the Assembly) was moved by Nehru in 1946. This resolution enshrined the aspirations and values behind the Constitution making. his made the moral commitment to establish a government that will fulfil the many promises that the nationalist movement held before the people of India.

Modern History.subject: Modern History
Modern History.question: Who was the first Nawab Wazir of Awadh in the 18th century?
Modern History.explanation: The Nawabs of Awadh were a clan of rulers that came from Persia in the early 18th century. Nawab Sa’adat Ali Khan, the first in the dynasty came from Persia in 1724 and established the state of Awadh at a time when the Mughal empire was shrinking. Taking advantage of the situation, he gained supremacy over Awadh and made Faizabad the capital.

Modern History.subject: Modern History
Modern History.question: The College of Fort William was established by which one of the following Governor-Generals?
Modern History.explanation: Fort William College was established on 18 August 1800 by Lord Richard Wellesley (d. 1837), Governor General of India, in order to provide instruction in the vernacular languages of India to the civil and military officials of the East India Company.

Modern History.subject: Modern History
Modern History.question: The Economic historian, who has used the data collected by BuchananHamilton to support the thesis of deindustrialization in the 19th century India, is
Modern History.explanation: Amiya Kumar Bagchi used Buchanan’s tables as a statistical database. He argued that Bihar experienced significant deindustrialisation in the 19th century as a result of the colonial British presence.

Modern History.subject: Modern History
Modern History.question: Tea growing in India in the 19th century was made possible by
Modern History.explanation: Tea growing in India in 19 century was made possible by Robert Fortune. Robert Fortune was a Scottish botanist, plant hunter, and traveler. He was best known for he had stolen tea from China during his employment in the British East India company.

Modern History.subject: Modern History
Modern History.question: Subhas Chandra Bose started the ‘Azad Hind Radio’ in which of the following countries?
Modern History.explanation: Azad Hind Radio was a propaganda radio service that was started under the leadership of Netaji Subhas Chandra Bose in Germany in 1942 to encourage Indians to fight for freedom.

Modern History.subject: Modern History
Modern History.question: Which political party formally accepted the Cabinet Mission Plan on 6th June, 1946. which had rejected the demand for a sovereign Pakistan?
Modern History.explanation: The cabinet mission recommended an undivided India and turned down the Muslim league’s demand for a separate Pakistan. The Cabinet mission restricted the Communal representation.

Modern History.subject: Modern History
Modern History.question: The elected President of the All India Kisan Sabha. which met in Vijayawada (1944), was
Modern History.explanation: Swami Sahajanad Saraswati was the elected president of All India Kisan Sabha at Vijayawada, Andhra Pradesh in 1944. It was the eight conference of All India Kisan Sabha, which was formed in 1936. Swami Sahajanad fist started the Kisan Sabha Movement in Bihar.

Modern History.subject: Modern History
Modern History.question: Who took over the ‘Eka Movement’ started by the Congress in Awadh during 1921-1922?
Modern History.explanation: Eka Movement or Unity Movement is a peasant movement which surfaced in Hardoi, Bahraich and Sitapur during the end of 1921 by Madari Pasi, an offshoot of Non Cooperation Movement. The initial thrust was given by the leaders of Congress and Khilafat movement.

Medieval History.subject: Medieval History
Medieval History.question: Who among the following European travellers never returned to Europe and settled down in India?
Medieval History.explanation: Niccolao Manucci was an Italian writer and traveller who visited India and spent almost his entire life there without going back to Europe again.

Medieval History.subject: Medieval History
Medieval History.question: The class of Amar Nayakas in Vijayanagara is a reference to which of the following?
Medieval History.explanation: The amara-nayaka system was a major political innovation of the Vijayanagara Empire. It is likely that many features of this system were derived from the iqta system of the Delhi Sultanate. The amara-nayakas were military commanders who were given territories to govern by the raya.

Medieval History.subject: Medieval History
Medieval History.question: The aristocrat Muqarrab Khan was a great favourite of which Mughal Emperor?
Medieval History.explanation: Aristocrat Muqrarab Khan was great favorite of Mughal Emperor Jahangier. Shaikh Hassan Hassu was the original name of Muqarrab Khan. The title of Muqarrab Khan was given to him by Jahangier. He was a great physician and surgeon during the time of Jahangier. Jahangier made him a mansabdar and appointed him the governor of three Subas. He once operated successfully the surgery of Jahangier which made him the favorite of Jahangier.

Medieval History.subject: Medieval History
Medieval History.question: According to the French traveller Tavernier, the majority of houses in Varanasi during the 17th century were made of
Medieval History.explanation: Jean Baptiste Tavernier travelled to Varanasi in India, in 1665. He described that houses and other structures were mostly made of mud and clay. Some had made use of stones, slate and wood. Jean Baptiste Tavernier was a traveller and gem merchant who made several voyages to Persia and India.
